content.description:
This a great traverse! Start standing on the right side of the southeast face with a couple of head height edges. Traverse left, using only holds below the lip. The crux comes early with a difficult move to match a vertical seam and move left from it to a gigantic flake. After gaining the flake, the difficulty eases, but there are still a few tricky bits. Keep traversing until reaching the northeast corner of the boulder (basically, where the two boulders touch) and top it out. Don't use the other boulder on the top out!

It is a really fun problem that is a great way to start or end the day.
content.protection: It is pretty low to the ground, so a pad isn't really needed (other than to clean your shoes - it keeps the rock from getting polished!). Just mind your landings.
content.location: When approaching the Egg Boulders from the T intersection, this problem will be on the far side of boulder closest to the trail. It begins just left of a large spruce/fir tree.

content.description: Start crouched with hands on opposing sidepulls. Make a big move to a good, but somewhat hidden, edge. It is a bit reachy for short folks.
content.location: This is located on the northwest arete of the main boulder.

content.description:
This lowball line is actually pretty fun.

Start sitting below the nose with your left hand on a sidepull at the lip and your right hand in a good four finger pocket. It is powerful for the grade.
content.location:
This is located on the small boulder located to the right of '

Egg Sandwich

'. It climbs the mini-nose/prow.

content.description:
Start standing with your hands on opposing sidepulls at 4-5 feet (essentially the same start as '

Walking On Eggshells

'). Head straight up to a somewhat tricky topout for the grade.

Be mindful of the rock in the landing zone.
content.location: This is the furthest route right on the main boulder at this area. It starts right next to a small block protruding out of the ground.
